TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit MultiSelector extends System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.Selector
Public MustInherit Class MultiSelector Inherits Selector

Docs.summary: Provides an abstract class for controls that allow multiple items to be selected.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you derive a class from the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector> class, set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.CanSelectMultipleItems%2A> property to `true` to allow multi-selection in your control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector> is an abstract class and cannot be instantiated directly.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig instance void BeginUpdateSelectedItems() cil managed

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.BeginUpdateSelectedItems%2A> method sets <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.IsUpdatingSelectedItems%2A> to `true`. The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.EndUpdateSelectedItems%2A> method sets <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.IsUpdatingSelectedItems%2A> to `false`.
## Examples The following example shows how to use the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.BeginUpdateSelectedItems%2A> method in a class derived from <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector>.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Controls.MultiSelectorEx#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/System.Windows.Controls.MultiSelectorEx/CS/MyMultiSelector.xaml.cs#2)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the multiple items in the can be selected at a time.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.CanSelectMultipleItems%2A> property to `true` in a derived class to allow multi-selection for that class.
## Examples The following code example shows how to set this property in a derived class.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Controls.MultiSelectorEx#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/System.Windows.Controls.MultiSelectorEx/CS/MyMultiSelector.xaml.cs#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig instance void EndUpdateSelectedItems() cil managed

Docs.summary: Commits the selected items to the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method sets <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.IsUpdatingSelectedItems%2A> to `false` and updates the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.SelectedItems%2A> collection.
The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.BeginUpdateSelectedItems%2A> method sets <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.IsUpdatingSelectedItems%2A> to `true`.
## Examples The following example shows how to use the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.EndUpdateSelectedItems%2A> method in a class derived from <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector>.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Controls.MultiSelectorEx#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/System.Windows.Controls.MultiSelectorEx/CS/MyMultiSelector.xaml.cs#2)]

Docs.summary: Selects all of the items in the .

remarks.format: ## Remarks You can use this method only if <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.CanSelectMultipleItems%2A> is `true`.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property SelectedItems As IList
public: property System::Collections::IList ^ SelectedItems { System::Collections::IList ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the items in the that are selected.
Docs.value: The items in the that are selected.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.CanSelectMultipleItems%2A> is `false`, you cannot add more than one item to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.SelectedItems%2A> collection. Attempts to do so will cause an exception.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void UnselectAll() cil managed

Docs.summary: Unselects all of the items in the .

remarks.format: ## Remarks You can use this method regardless of whether <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.MultiSelector.CanSelectMultipleItems%2A> is `true` or `false`.
